headline: The Bull Case For Exxon Mobil (XOM) Could Change Following Record Output And Massive Buybacks – Learn Why
summary: Exxon Mobil’s late-January 2026 update combined a first-quarter US$1.03 per-share dividend declaration, completion of a US$71.65 billion buyback program, and fourth-quarter 2025 earnings of US$6.50 billion on revenue of US$82.31 billion, with earnings per share of US$1.53. Despite lower quarterly profit than a year earlier, the company delivered its highest annual upstream production in over four decades, realized substantial structural cost savings, and continued expanding carbon capture...

headline: Energy giant sends blunt $20 billion message on dividend growth
summary: When oil prices tank, most energy companies pull back. ExxonMobil -- a dividend aristocrat -- did the opposite. The Texas-based oil giant wrapped up $20 billion in share repurchases last year while crude posted its steepest annual drop since the pandemic. That aggressive buyback program ...

headline: Exxon Mobil (XOM) Valuation Check After Q4 Beat Powered By Permian And Guyana Output
summary: Exxon Mobil (XOM) just reported fourth quarter 2025 results that came in ahead of expectations, helped by record full year upstream output from the Permian Basin and Guyana, as well as meaningful cost savings. See our latest analysis for Exxon Mobil. The recent earnings beat, dividend declaration and ongoing buybacks have come alongside a strong share price run, with a 30 day share price return of 15.29% and a 1 year total shareholder return of 36.88%, suggesting momentum has been building...

headline: A $58 Billion Shale Merger Comes at an Awkward Time
summary: Oil and gas producers  Devon Energy  and  Coterra Energy  are joining forces to become a dominant $58 billion shale-drilling company that will rank among the top players in U.S.-based production.  Analysts seem to like the deal, but shares of both Devon and  Coterra  were down 0.5% and 3%, respectively, early on Monday.  Part of the problem was that oil prices were falling Monday.

headline: Exxon Mobil CCS Launch Tests Valuation And Momentum At US$141 Share Price
summary: Exxon Mobil (NYSE:XOM) has started commercial operations at a large carbon capture and storage project in Louisiana. The project is developed with CF Industries and is intended to capture and store industrial carbon emissions. Exxon has also secured additional agreements with other industrial partners for future CCS services. For investors watching Exxon Mobil at a current share price of $141.4, this move adds another operational asset tied directly to its carbon management efforts. The...

headline: Devon Agrees to Buy Oil Rival Coterra for $21.4 Billion in Stock
summary: The deal calls for Coterra stockholders to receive 0.7 Devon shares for each share they own, according to a statement Monday.  The company will keep the Devon name, and Devon Chief Executive Officer Clay Gaspar will remain as CEO after the deal closes.  Bloomberg News first reported the talks earlier this year and revealed last week that a deal was near.

raw.headline: Devon Agrees to Buy Oil Rival Coterra for $21.4 Billion in Stock

headline: Want To Feel Dumb? Try Picking Stocks
summary: On Friday morning, America’s two largest oil-and-gas producers,  Exxon Mobil  and  Chevron released annual results.  Unless the results changed their view on the whole energy sector, though, all the buying and selling was mostly a waste of time.

headline: NextEra Energy Targets Data Center Demand With Nuclear And Carbon Capture
summary: NextEra Energy is working on power deals with major tech firms to support electricity hungry data centers. The company is exploring nuclear fleet expansion and record renewables additions to meet rising server load. NextEra is in advanced talks on a new gas power plant with carbon capture in partnership with ExxonMobil. For investors watching NYSE:NEE, this data center push comes as the stock trades around $87.9 and has returned 26.7% over the past year. Multi year returns of 28.4% over 3...
